choices.A: NPO at midnight, and RL or NS at 75-100cc/h
choices.B: RL or NS at 75-100cc/h NPO at midnight
choices.D: NPO at midnight with RL or NS @ 150cc/h

Q001.question: Your patient, Ms. Deforest, was just admitted and scheduled for surgery tomorrow but there is nothing in her admission orders about diet or IV fluids. What would you like to be done?

choices.A: Bed rest since she has a history of epilepsy
choices.B: No blowing her nose because of the maxillary sinus fracture
choices.C: Non-weight bearing because she has surgery tomorrow

Q002.question: Your patient, Mrs. Poulin, was admitted today but there is nothing in her admission orders about activity. Does she have any activity restrictions?

choices.A: Acetaminophen po/pr, Advil po, Dilaudid po and sc, Gravol po/iv, Zofran po/iv, Trazodone po, Enoxaparin sc
choices.B: Acetaminophen po/pr, Dilaudid po and sc, Gravol po/iv, Zofran po/iv, Trazodone po, Enoxaparin sc
choices.C: Acetaminophen po/pr, Advil po, Dilaudid po and sc, Gravol po/iv, Zopiclone po, Enoxaparin sc
choices.D: Acetaminophen po/pr, Dilaudid po and sc, Gravol po/iv, Zopiclone po, Enoxaparin sc

Q003.question: Your patient, Mr. Levine, was admitted this morning. We cannot find orders for what drugs to give other than those he takes at home. What types of drugs should be listed?

choices.A: Replace NG losses 1:1 with NS +20mEq KCl
choices.B: Replace NG losses 1:1 with 2/3 + 1/3 to ensure he has glucose
choices.D: No, do not replace his NG losses

Q004.question: Your patient, Mr. Oman, has an NG tube ordered on his admission orders. There is nothing else written with this and he has lost 2L via NG today. Would you like anything to be given to the patient once the NG tube is inserted?

choices.A: Dr. Smith, as he is her OB
choices.B: Dr. Jones, as he is her FMD
choices.C: Dr. Ali, as he will look after her going forward
choices.D: Dr. Ali, but her care might be transferred to Dr. Smith in the morning
choices.E: Dr. Smith in case she delivers overnight, but if not, then Dr. Jones in the morning

Q005.question: It is midnight and your patient, Mrs. Paquet, was just admitted, but there is no physician named on her admission orders. Her obstetrician is Dr. Smith and her FMD is Dr. Jones. They both have admitting privileges at the hospital. You are on call with Dr. Ali. Who should we put as admitting physician?

choices.A: No, it should be 130cc
choices.C: Yes, because she is a fresh post-op so slightly lower than usual is acceptable
choices.D: Yes, because anything over 30cc is okay given her weight

Q006.question: Your patient, Ms. Kader, is in PACU. The nurse calls you worried that her urine output is low. Her urine output is 100cc over the last 4 hours. Is this okay?

choices.A: No, if she becomes more tachycardic we can consider ordering fluids.
choices.B: No, she is on the appropriate maintenance fluids
choices.C: Yes, increase her maintenance fluids to 150cc/hr x 4 hours
choices.D: Yes, give her a 1L bolus of NS

Q007.question: Ms. Labelle is slightly tachycardic at 102. She has had ongoing diarrhea, but her C. diff cultures are negative. She has maintenance fluids running at 100cc/hr. Do you want to order anything?

choices.A: Yes, because his Hb, Plt, and Cr have also increased and therefore it is likely a reflection of dehydration
choices.B: Yes, because the presence of the stone accounts for the WBC
choices.C: No, because his Hb, Plt, and Cr have also increased and therefore he may have another focus of infection like pneumonia or C. Diff
choices.D: No, it is elevated and therefore we should start antibiotics

Q008.question: Mr. Maguire has been in hospital for 3 days. His WBC has always been normal. Today it is 13. Is this okay?

choices.A: Give a 1L bolus of IV NS as his Hb is still >70
choices.B: Give a 1L bolus of IV NS until 1u of type and crossed pRBC arrives
choices.D: Repeat Hb in 12 hours to determine need for crystalloid vs. blood product

Q009.question: Mr. Ljungborg’s Hb has dropped from 91 to 76 over 24 hours. What would you like to do?

choices.A: Hold his Lasix tonight, he doesn’t need it.
choices.B: Have him try to take it po, it’s very important that he has it.
choices.C: Give him 40mg of Lasix IV for today
choices.D: Give him 20mg of Lasix IV for today

Q010.question: Mr. Öman takes 40mg of Lasix po daily at home. He is unable to tolerate anything by mouth now because of severe nausea and vomiting. What should I do about his Lasix?

choices.A: Monitor Na q4H and correct with NS at 0.5mEq/L/h
choices.B: Monitor Na q4H and correct with 3% Saline at 1.5 mEq/L/h
choices.C: This does not need to be treated because she has known renal insufficiency
choices.D: This does not need to be treated because she is on RL for maintenance fluids

Q011.question: Your patient, Ms. Desforest, has a Na of 117. She does not have volume overload and is asymptomatic. How should you treat this?

choices.A: Monitor Na q4H and correct with NS at 0.5mEq/L/h
choices.B: Monitor Na q4H and correct with 3% Saline at 1.5 mEq/L/h
choices.C: Give diazepam because she is at risk of a seizure
choices.D: Give her Tylenol +/- Tramadol for her H/A

Q012.question: Your patient, Ms. Desforest, has a Na of 110. She does not have volume overload but has a severe headache. How should you treat this?

choices.A: K-exalate 15-30g PO q4-6h and an ECG
choices.C: K-dur 40 mEq po q4-6h and an ECG
choices.D: K-elixir 40 mEq po q4-6h and an ECG

Q013.question: Your patient, Mrs. Lavigne, was put on labetalol during her surgery last night. Her potassium is now 6.0. How should she be managed?

choices.A: Hypokalemia

Q014.question: Your patient, Mr. Maguire, had an ECG this morning. It showed an increased amplitude and width of the P wave, T wave flattening and inversion, and ST depression. What do you think is going on?

choices.A: K-elixir 20-40mEq PO
choices.C: Don’t correct it, as it is still in an an acceptable range

Q015.question: Your patient, Mr. Maguire, has a potassium of 3.2. How should this be corrected?

choices.A: It is not correctly placed: it is in the esophagus
choices.B: It is not correctly placed: it is the L mainstem bronchus
choices.C: It is not correctly placed: it is in the R mainstem bronchus
choices.D: It is not correctly placed: but it is in the trachea

Q016.question: Your patient, Ms. Desforest, was intubated emergently. Her O2 sats are not great. Can you confirm that the ETT is correctly placed? [IMG]https://emcow.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/r-mainstem-intubation.jpg

choices.A: Urine sodium because he may have AKI with low urine Na
choices.B: BUN and creatinine because he may have an AKI with low U/O
choices.C: Hb in case bleeding is causing his low U/O
choices.D: Urine glucose in case he has diabetes

Q017.question: Your patient, Mr Hunter, is complaining of a headache, nausea, fatigue, and thirst. He has decreased urine output. What is the most appropriate test to order?

choices.A: Yes, CXR to look for pneumonia
choices.C: Yes, but only if he is febrile
choices.D: Yes, CXR to look for COPD

Q018.question: Your patient, Mr. Levine, has had a productive cough with yellow sputum since yesterday morning and said he had chills throughout the night. Do you want to order any tests?

choices.A: Yes, because the NG tip is in the stomach
choices.B: No, because the NG tip is in small bowel
choices.C: Yes, because the NG tip is past the carina, and below the diaphragm in the upper part of the stomach
choices.D: No because the NG tip is not advanced far enough to reach the stomach

Q019.question: Your patient, Mr. Oman, had an NG tube put in this morning. Can you confirm if it is placed correctly? [IMG]http://bjmp.org/files/march2009/bjmp0309melarkode3.jpg

choices.A: No, those tests are sufficient for this patient’s pre-operative plan
choices.B: Yes, he should have a CXR and ECG as baseline
choices.C: No, because he has a CT chest

Q020.question: Your patient, Mr. Oman is going for surgery tomorrow. All we have is standard bloodwork and a CT chest/abdo/pelvis on file. Do you want to order any more tests before surgery?

choices.A: CK, TnI and repeat in 8 hours x 2 and CBC, lytes, Cr
choices.D: CK, TnI x 2 now, Type & cross

Q021.question: Your patient, Mr. Patrickson, has a heavy feeling in his chest that is radiating to his jaw. He also feels nauseous. His CXR and ECG were normal. Do you want to order any other tests?

choices.A: Yes, it is correctly placed in the SVC just above the heart
choices.B: Yes, it is correctly placed in the R atrium
choices.C: No, it is advanced too far into the cardiac chambers
choices.D: No, it is in the subclavian vein

Q022.question: Your patient, Mr. Lehrer, had a PICC line put in this morning. Can you confirm that it is correctly placed? [IMG]http://www.vcuthoracicimaging.com/Imagewindow.aspx?imgname=Uploadimg%5CPicture10713216853750.jpg&caption=

choices.A: No, this is normal given her COPD
choices.B: No, this is normal given her Supraglottic laryngeal SCC
choices.C: Yes, give her O2 to keep sats >92%
choices.D: Yes, order an ABG and give her O2 to keep her sats >92%

Q023.question: Mr. Mohammed’s O2 is at 89% RA. Do you want to do anything?

choices.A: CBC, lytes, BUN, and Cr daily in a.m.
choices.B: CBC q8h x 48h then R/A, lytes, BUN, and Cr daily in a.m.
choices.C: CBC, lytes, BUN, and Cr q8h x 48h then R/A
choices.D: CBC q8h x 48h then R/A, lytes, extended lyes, BUN, Cr, urine Na, and urine Cr daily in a.m

Q024.question: Your patient, Mr. Ljungborg, has no post-op orders. In terms of labs, what would you like to be monitored?

choices.A: No, it is in the trachea
choices.B: No, it needs to be removed and re-placed
choices.C: No, it needs to be advanced further
choices.D: No, but it can be used for suction, just not for feeding

Q025.question: Your patient, Mrs. El-Hashem, had an NG tube put in this morning. Can you confirm that the NG tube is in the correct position? [IMG]http://bjmp.org/files/march2009/bjmp0309melarkode4.jpg

choices.A: Yes, it is in the trachea, at the carina
choices.B: No, it is in the R mainstem bronchus
choices.C: No, it needs to be advanced further
choices.D: Yes, it it in the trachea, 2cm above the carina

Q026.question: Your patient, Mr. Matsushita, had an ETT placed this morning. Can you confirm that the ETT is in the right location? [IMG]http://bjmp.org/files/march2009/bjmp0309melarkode1.jpg

choices.A: Order basic blood work and CT PE
choices.B: Order basic blood work and a D-dimer
choices.C: Order basic blood work and do a Doppler of his legs in the morning
choices.D: Oder basic blood work and CK/TnI

Q027.question: Your patient, Mr. Ralph, is short of breath. He is on a non-rebreather and his ECG and CXR look normal. Do you want to order any more tests?

choices.A: Yes, please restart her warfarin at her home dose (5mg po daily)
choices.B: Yes, please give her enoxaparin 40mg sc qHs since she is no longer anticoagulated
choices.C: No, do not give her anything tonight
choices.D: No, not until she reaches an INR of 1.0.

Q028.question: Your patient, Ms. Desforest, has had her warfarin held for the last 4 days. Her INR is now 1.3. Would you like to give her any anticoagulation for tonight?

choices.A: When his INR is <1.4, which is likely in 3-5 days time
choices.B: He can go for surgery now, if his INR is reversed with octaplex
choices.C: He can go for surgery now
choices.D: He can go for surgery now, if his INR is reversed with Vitamin K
choices.E: When his INR is <1.4, which is likely in 8-12 hours with VitK

Q029.question: Your patient, Mr. Ihejirika, is still on warfarin and his INR is 2.4. If we stop warfarin today, when can he be rescheduled for surgery?

choices.A: Daily enoxaparin 40mg SC
choices.C: Nothing as he has not had any VTE in the past
choices.D: Nothing, until his INR is sub-therapeutic, then enoxaparin 40mg sc

Q030.question: Your patient, Mr. Ihejirika, has been taken off warfarin. How will you manage his anticoagulation?

choices.A: Because it’s a major surgery, with a high risk of throwing clots, restart immediately
choices.B: Because it’s a major surgery, with high risk of bleeding, restart 24-48 hours post-op
choices.C: He does not need Dabigatran post-op because his surgery was successful
choices.D: He should be switched to Warfarin post-op because he will likely have fluctuations in his anticoagulation status

Q031.question: Your patient, Mr. Lehrer, has been taken off of Dabigatran in preparation for surgery. How soon after surgery can it be restarted?

choices.A: POD#1, and bridge with LMWH until his INR is >2
choices.B: He should be transitioned to a NOAC instead of warfarin because he does not have a high risk of falls and it is more user-friendly
choices.C: This should not be re-started yet, but reassessed in a few days

Q032.question: Your patient, Mr. Ljungborg, had his warfarin stopped for surgery. When should this be restarted?

choices.A: SCDs
choices.B: Not until he is no longer at risk of bleeding

Q033.question: Your patient, Mr. Ljungborg, has not been restarted on anticoagulation. Is there anything else we can do to decrease his risk of DVT?

choices.A: He has DM, HTN, and afib
choices.B: He is immobile and has cancer (2 of 3 Virchow’s triad)
choices.C: Prostate mobilization will increase his risk of clot
choices.D: Because he was immunosuppressed when on chemotherapy

Q034.question: Your patient, Mr. Doyle, is at high risk of stroke. Why?

choices.A: No, we will re-check his INR the morning of surgery
choices.B: Yes, Vitamin K to reverse his INR before surgery
choices.C: Yes, Octaplex to reverse his INR before surgery
choices.D: No, his INR will be fine for surgery

Q035.question: Your patient, Mr. Scheinberg, has an INR of 2.4. You have just stopped his warfarin. Would you like to order anything else?

choices.A: Stop Dabigatran now, but he will likely need his OR postponed 2-3 more days
choices.B: Stop Dabigatran now, yes there is enough time
choices.C: Continue Dabigatran until the night before surgery

Q036.question: Your patient, Mr. Lehrer, needs to have his anticoagulation managed before surgery. What medications need to be stopped/started? Is there still enough time before his surgery?

choices.A: Ancef 2g IV

Q037.question: Your patient, Mr. Ihejirika, is going for surgery. What antibiotics and what dose will he need? He weighs 85kg.

choices.A: He should receive Vancomycin within 60 minutes of cut time (ideally within 30 mins)
choices.B: He should receive Vancomycin via infusion, started 120 mins before cut time
choices.C: He should receive Ancef within 60 minutes of cut time (ideally within 30 mins)
choices.D: He should receive Ancef via infusion, started 120 mins before cut time

Q038.question: Your patient, Mr. Ihejirika, has antibiotics ordered to be given before surgery tomorrow. When exactly should these antibiotics be given?

choices.A: Vancomycin at 15mg/kg (1g IV)

Q039.question: Your patient, Mr. Specter, is having surgery today. What antibiotics and what dose should be given? He weighs 60kg.

choices.A: He should receive Vancomycin within 60 minutes of cut time (ideally within 30 mins)
choices.B: He should receive Vancomycin via infusion, started 120 mins before cut time
choices.C: He should receive Ancef within 60 minutes of cut time (ideally within 30 mins)
choices.D: He should receive Ancef via infusion, started 120 mins before cut time

Q040.question: 1.	Your patient, Mr. Specter, has antibiotics ordered to be given before surgery tomorrow. When exactly should these antibiotics be given?

choices.A: Ancef 1-2g IV

Q041.question: Your patient, Mrs. Poulin, requires gram negative antibiotic coverage. What antibiotic and what dose should be ordered?

choices.A: Yes, she needs Cipro 400mg IV + Flagyl 500 mg IV and should be given less than 30 min before incision made
choices.B: Yes, she needs 1 g IV Ancef and should be given less than 30 min before incision made
choices.C: Yes, she needs 1 g IV Ancef re-dosed for 4 hours after her last dose of antibiotic to cover her intra-operatively
choices.D: No, since she already received Cipro + Flagyl, she should just continue with the normal dosing schedule

Q042.question: Your patient, Ms. Rey, is already on Cipro + Flagyl. Her last dose was 3 hours ago. Do any antibiotics need to be ordered for her surgery?

choices.A: No, because this is Class I surgery (clean)
choices.B: No, because this is Class II surgery (clean-contaminated)
choices.C: Yes, because this is Class II surgery (clean-contaminated)
choices.D: Yes, because he has a prosthetic valve

Q043.question: Your patient, Mr. Scheinberg, is going for surgery. Does he require antibiotic prophylaxis?

choices.A: Ancef 2g IV

Q044.question: Your patient, Mr. Salomon, needs antibiotics before surgery. He weighs 100kg. What antibiotic and what dose do you want?

choices.A: Take usual morning steroid dose
choices.C: Take usual morning steroid dose, give 100 mg of IV hydrocortisone before induction of anesthesia and 50 mg q8h for 24 hours.
choices.D: Give 100 mg of IV hydrocortisone before induction of anesthesia and 50 mg q8h for 24 hours

Q045.question: Your patient, Ms. Desforest, was tested for her morning serum cortisol and it showed that her HPA axis is suppressed. Considering she is having a major surgery tomorrow, what should she be given tomorrow morning?

choices.A: Take usual morning steroid dose
choices.C: Take usual morning steroid dose, give 100 mg of IV hydrocortisone before induction of anesthesia and 50 mg q8h for 24 hours.
choices.D: Give 100 mg of IV hydrocortisone before induction of anesthesia and 50 mg q8h for 24 hours

Q046.question: Your patient, Mr. Specter, is going for surgery tomorrow. Does he need a stress dose of steroids before surgery?

choices.A: No, he doesn’t need an oral hypoglycemic agent since he is NPO
choices.B: No, because he cannot take pills while NPO
choices.C: Yes, because Metformin does not cause hypoglycemia
choices.D: Yes, because he is not NPO

Q047.question: Your patient, Mr. Levine, is on metformin. Can this be continued?

choices.A: 8-10 mmol/L, insulin subcutaneous

Q048.question: Your patient, Mr. Oman, needs to have his glucose monitored. What should his target glucose be and what drug and method of delivery should be used?

choices.A: IV NS

Q049.question: Your patient, Mr. Oman, is on metformin. What IV fluids would you like to give while he is NPO?

choices.A: Hypoglycemia. Give oral source of sugar.

Q050.question: Your patient, Mr. Oman, is sweating, has tremors, a heart rate of 110 and says he feels both hungry and nauseous. What do you think is going on and what can he be given?

choices.A: Diabetic diet, blood glucose monitoring 4x/day. Continue normal diabetes management. Low dose sliding scale.
choices.B: DAT, blood glucose monitoring 4x/day. Continue normal diabetes management. Low dose sliding scale.
choices.C: NPO, blood glucose monitoring 4x/day. Continue normal diabetes management. Low dose sliding scale.
choices.D: NPO, blood glucose monitoring 4x/day. Half basal insulin dose, continue metformin, start on 2/3 + 1/3 IV @ 100cc/hr. Low dose sliding scale.

Q051.question: Your patient, Ms. Afolayan, was just admitted this morning. There was nothing written on her admission orders regarding her diabetes. What should it say?

choices.A: Diabetic diet, blood glucose monitoring 4x/day. Continue normal diabetes management. Low dose sliding scale.
choices.B: DAT, blood glucose monitoring 4x/day. Continue normal diabetes management. Low dose sliding scale.
choices.C: NPO, blood glucose monitoring 4x/day. Continue normal diabetes management. Low dose sliding scale.
choices.D: NPO, blood glucose monitoring 4x/day. Half basal insulin dose, continue metformin, start on 2/3 + 1/3 IV @ 100cc/hr. Low dose sliding scale.

Q052.question: It is 2 am, and your patient, Mr. Doyle, has no admission orders regarding his diabetes. What should it say?

choices.A: Start metformin and glucoscans with insulin sliding scale
choices.B: Start glucoscans with insulin sliding scale, and consult endocrinology and DM nurse
choices.C: Nothing, have her family doctor follow up

Q053.question: Your patient, Ms. El-Hashem, blood results came back. Her HbA1c is 8.3%. What do you want to order?

choices.A: Start metformin and glucoscans with insulin sliding scale
choices.B: Start glucoscans with insulin sliding scale, and consult endocrinology and DM nurse
choices.C: Nothing, have her family doctor follow up

Q054.question: Your patient, Ms. Kwok, has an HbA1c of 5.2%. What do you want to do?

choices.A: a.	Investigations and management done thus far in hospital stay
choices.B: History of presenting illness, physical exam,and past medical history
choices.C: a.	Have a specific question for ID

Q055.question: 1.	You would like to consult ID regarding Mr. Hunter. What information do you require before making this consult?

choices.A: Radiology

Q056.question: Your patient, Mr. Mohammed, is going for surgery tomorrow. This is a picture of Mr. Mohammed. Would you like to consult any services before he goes for surgery? [IMG]http://www.mdpi.com/polymers/polymers-04-00691/article_deploy/html/images/polymers-04-00691-g003-1024.png

choices.A: Hematology

Q057.question: Your patient, Mr. Oman, is going for surgery tomorrow. Would you like to consult anyone prior to his surgery?

choices.A: No, not until you have the necessary information (labs, imaging etc.)
choices.B: No, there is no indication for a medicine consult
choices.C: Yes, medicine should be involved in a patient with dementia as this is a non-surgical issue
choices.D: Yes, he is not a surgical candidate given his dementia, therefore medicine should be called for admission.

Q058.question: A new patient just came into the ER with a fractured radius. He has severe dementia. Would you like to consult medicine?

choices.A: Radiology

Q059.question: 1.	Your patient, Mr. Maguire, is going for surgery in 2 days. Would you like to consult anyone prior to her surgery?

choices.A: No, his condition is stable and therefore a medicine consult is not necessary.
choices.B: No, there is no indication for a medicine consult.
choices.C: a.	Yes, medicine should be involved in a patient with COPD.
choices.D: Yes, he is not a surgical candidate given his COPD, therefore medicine should be called for admission.

Q060.question: A new patient just came into the ER with a third degree burn. He has an O2 sat of 89% on 3L NP, a sputum-producing cough, and a hx of COPD. His condition is currently stable. Would you like to consult medicine?

choices.A: Internal medicine

Q061.question: Your patient, Mr. Maguire, is experiencing diarrhea 10x/day and severe stomach pain. His C. Diff culture is negative. Would you like to consult anyone prior to his surgery?

choices.A: No, not until you have a more complete past medical history.
choices.B: No, his medical issues were well-managed in Pembroke, so there probably isn’t anything to optimize
choices.C: Yes, he is 78 and you know his past medical history is complex, so you should consult internal medicine and/or anesthesia
choices.D: Yes, his cancer should be assessed by oncology prior to surgery

Q062.question: Your patient, Mr. Doyle, was transferred from Pembroke. You don’t yet have any of his past medical history or medication list, and he can only tell you he had cancer and has been in hospital many times. Would you like to consult anyone prior to his surgery?

choices.A: EtOH withdrawal: diazepam 5 – 20 mg PO, thiamine 100 mg PO daily, IV fluids and electrolyte replacement
choices.B: EtOH withdrawal: diazepam 5 – 20 mg PO, IV fluids and electrolyte replacement
choices.C: Delirium tremens. Midazolam or diazepam 5 – 10 mg IV as bolus every 5 – 15 minutes until patient is sedated

Q063.question: Your patient, Mr. Specter, seems agitated, has a fine tremor, and has a heart rate of 120. What do you think is wrong and what do you want to do?

choices.A: EtOH withdrawal: diazepam 5 – 20 mg PO, thiamine 100 mg PO daily, IV fluids and electrolyte replacement
choices.C: Hypothyroid: give thyroxin at usual home dose
choices.D: Delirium tremens. Midazolam or diazepam 5 – 10 mg IV as bolus every 5 – 15 minutes until patient is sedated

Q064.question: Your patient, Mr. Levine, appears to be having hallucinations, is very scared, and is shaking. His pupils are dilated. What do you think is wrong and what do you want to do?

choices.A: EtOH withdrawal

Q065.question: Your patient, Mr. Scheinburg, is showing signs of confusion. He hasn’t been given any new medications, is normally very pleasant, and doesn’t show any signs of infection. What do you think is the most likely cause of this?

choices.A: No, because it will prolong his QT
choices.B: No, because the usual dose is 25-50mg po qHS prn
choices.C: Yes, because patients are often unable to sleep in hospital
choices.D: Yes, because he has asked for a sleep aid.

Q066.question: Your patient, Mr. Ralph, is upset because he cannot sleep. He is AVSS and AAOx3. Can I give him 150mg Trazadone to help him sleep?

choices.A: Yes, Haloperidol 1mg po/sl q2h prn

Q067.question: Your patient, Mrs. Kwok, cannot seem to remember that her daughter visited today and is slightly upset. Do you want to give her any medication?

choices.A: No, you should transfuse if platelets <50
choices.B: No, you should transfuse if platelets <10
choices.C: Transfuse platelets because high risk surgery and platelets <100
choices.D: Transfuse platelets because having surgery and platelets <250

Q068.question: Your patient, Ms. Desforest has a platelet count of 90. How would you like to proceed with treatment?

choices.A: Transfuse 1u pRBC in case he is bleeding
choices.C: No transfusion, but consider intraoperatively for blood loss
choices.D: Give EPO injection prior to incision

Q069.question: Your patient, Mr. Specter, has a hemoglobin of 75 but feels completely normal. How would you like to proceed with treatment?

choices.A: D/C Warfarin, give 40mL of Octaplex, and order Vit K 1-2mg IV
choices.C: D/C Warfarin, order Vit K 1-2mg IV

Q070.question: Your patient, Mrs. Poulin, is an emergency case. Her INR is 3.0 and she weighs 60kg. How would you like to manage her anticoagulation?

choices.A: Transfuse 1u pRBC of O neg

Q071.question: Your patient, Mrs. Rey, has a hemoglobin of 60 and is experiencing orthostatic hypotension. She is not type & screened. How would you like to proceed with treatment?

choices.A: Transfuse 1u pRBC of O neg

Q072.question: Your patient, Mr. Salomon, has a hemoglobin of 69 and is experiencing orthostatic hypotension. He is not type and screened. How would you like to proceed with treatment?

choices.A: Only if she is symptomatic (orthostatic hypotension, dizzy, H/A)

Q073.question: Your patient, Mrs. Rey, has a hemoglobin of 60. She is AAOx3, and wondering what is going on. Can the nurse go ahead and transfuse her with pRBC?

choices.A: Only if he is symptomatic (orthostatic hypotension, dizzy, H/A)

Q074.question: Your patient, Mr. Oman, has a hemoglobin of 60 and is experiencing fatigue, weakness, and orthostatic hypotension. Can the nurse go ahead and transfuse him with pRBC?

choices.A: Transfuse Mrs. Zhu for Hb<80
choices.B: Don’t transfuse, because Hb is stable
choices.C: Don’t transfuse until Hb<70 or asymptomatic

Q075.question: Your patient, Mrs. Zhu, has a stable hemoglobin of 75 and feels well. How would you like to proceed with treatment?

choices.A: Over 4 hours
choices.B: Over 4 hours, and monitored closely for the first 15 mins
choices.C: Over 4 hours, and monitored closely for the duration of transfusion
